subject: RE: [junit] Simplified exception handling in tests
msgSnippet: Thanks for your helpful advice! When you say to only catch exceptions that I expect do you mean for test cases where the proper behaviour of the method under
messageBody:
Thanks for your helpful advice!

When you say to "only catch exceptions that I expect" do you mean for test cases where the proper behaviour of the method under test is to throw a particular exception? Your example shows a "return" in the catch block so I would think that is a "test passed" result.

I'll look at the AssertionFailedError with great interest -- the lack of an accurate stacktrace is so frustrating!

John

From: Vladimir R. Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
Sent: Friday, April 04, 2003 8:30 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Simplified exception handling in tests



> Here's a snippet of code from one of our unit tests:
>
> try {
> ClientSBHome home = (ClientSBHome) getEJBHome( jndiName, ClientSBHome.class );
> sessionBean = home.create();
> } catch( NamingException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " + e.toString() );
> } catch( CreateException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " + e.toString() );
> } catch( RemoteException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " + e.toString() );
> }
>
> All three exceptions are considered failures -- no special handling of any. My inclination is to simplify this code by collapsing the catch blocks into one. Comments?
>
> try {
> ClientSBHome home = (ClientSBHome) getEJBHome( jndiName, ClientSBHome.class );
> sessionBean = home.create();
> } catch( Exception e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " + e.toString() );
> }

you should only catch exceptions that you expect. For example if a
method has to throw a "CreateException", then catchin gthis exception:

catch (CreateException e) {
return;
}

will solve the problem. The other exceptions are simply caught by the
framework.

The easiest thing to do is add a "throw Exception" to the method
signature. Read the JUnit FAQ, it's explained in detail.

another thing:
catch (Exception e) {
fail("blah" + e.toString())
}

won't give you any detail about the stacktrace. So go figure out where
the NullPointerException was thrown! To solve this, you can either
modify the signature (see above) or use the
junitx.f.AssertionFailedError of the JUnit-addons package. This
exception accepts a Throwable as attribute and is 100% compatible with
JUnit.

-Vladimir
